title: Drought-hit ZImbabwe sells young elephants overseas despite fears they will be traumatised
text:
Zimbabwe has flown up to 30 young elephants overseas despite animal welfare group's concern they could be traumatized.

The animals - believed to have been sent to China - have been separated from their families for a year.

However Zimbabwe's National Parks service claim that it needs the money to support other wildlife during a devastating drought which has already killed 55 elephants.

The animals - believed to have been sent to China - have been separated from their families for a year (file image)

Tenashi Farawo, a spokesman for Zimbabwe's National Parks, told BBC News that proceeds from the sale of the elephants would be used to dig wells to save other wildlife in Hwangi National Park.

He also accused campaigners of trying to stir up public anger.

Lenin Chisaira, director of the Advocates4Earth environmental group, has criticised the decision saying when the animals are sent oversees or to zoos they are 'broken down in a very cruel manner'.

In August, the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) approved a proposal stating that elephants from Africa should no longer be sold outside the continent - however, it is yet to come into force.

At least 55 elephants have starved to death in the last two months in Zimbabwe's biggest national park, Hwange.

A drought has forced the animals to go out into nearby communities in the hope of finding food and water.

The animals also destroy crops and kill people as they stray from Zimbabwe's wildlife parks.

At least 55 elephants have starved to death in the last two months in Zimbabwe's biggest national park, Hwange (file image)

The drought has also affected other animals, with the wildlife agency drilling 1300ft wells to find drinking water which is safe for the animals.

Zimbabwe has one of Africa's largest elephant populations, and campaigners have recently appealed for the current hunting ban to be relaxed to keep numbers down.

The proliferation of ivory bans worldwide has led to a huge decline in exports – with the UK enacting a bill last year.

Botswana, which also has a large elephant population, lifted a ban on elephant hunting earlier this year in an attempt to decrease conflict and bring in revenue to the country.
description: The animals - believed to have been sent to China -  have been separated from their families for a year. The National Parks service claim that it needs the money to support other wildlife during the drought.
